hints.content:
Lets figure out the factors for the rows and columns. Then we can multiply to find the missing values.

![The same table as above, marked with a multiplication symbol.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/caa3c0cadb988aade1502fabb96d469232f98b67)

$40 \stackrel{\tealE{+8}}{\longrightarrow} 48 \stackrel{\tealE{+8}}{\longrightarrow} 56$

The factor for the third row is $\tealE{8}$.

![The same table as above, with the third row labeled 8.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ac4ba075cbae3658140606dc09e91d3ebd492070)

The factor for each row of a multiplication table is one more than the row above it.

![The same table as above, with the rows labeled 6, 7, and 8 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/ec24bf5685a33204f8202ccb82049bf9007b3f43)

$42 \stackrel{\blueE{+7}}{\longrightarrow} 49 \stackrel{\blueE{+7}}{\longrightarrow} 56$

The factor for the third column is $\blueE{7}$.

![The same table as above, with the third column labeled 7.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/254beab8dbf20113975f93d05e96810ddf9ac890)

The factor for each column of a multiplication table is one more than the column left of it.

![The same table as above, with the columns labeled 5, 6, and 7 respectively.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/0a865d6515a84ae4e018369c5b674165969cba06)

Now we know the factors, so we can multiply to find the missing numbers.

$6 \times 5 = 30$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 6 and column 5 labeled 30.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/1cde81dd9f7bcfd1f9f4bf66437f49f12d0bf81e)

$6 \times 6 = 36$

![The same table as above, with intersection of row 6 and column 6 labeled 36.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/b330b104885d29688fd70a9f449419ea2fd9fee8)

Here is the completed pattern.

[[☃ image 1]]

options.alt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads 30, 36, 42. The second row reads 35, 42, 49. The third row reads 40, 48, 56. !

question.content:
Part of a multiplication table is below.

**Complete the pattern in the multiplication table.**

[[☃ label-image 1]]

options.imageAlt: A partial multiplication table with 3 rows and 3 columns. The first row reads an unknown number, an unknown number, 42. The second row reads 35, 42, 49. The third row reads 40, 48, 56.

markers.label: The unknown number in the first row and first column
The unknown number in the first row and second column
